Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Situation2: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Story: I sit in the control tower, headset pressing into my ears, eyes darting between radar blips. The radio crackles with pilots’ voices, each one depending on me to guide them safely through the chaos. A sudden route closure has turned the sky into a tangled knot of holding patterns, and every second counts. My hands hover over the console, calculating, prioritizing, trying to keep everyone safe. But my phone vibrates insistently in my pocket—my mother’s name flashes on the screen. I know what she wants: tonight is the family’s annual tradition, a ritual my parents have reminded me about all week. “It’s not just a dinner,” my father said, “it’s who we are.” I promised I’d be there, that I wouldn’t let work come between us. But now, as the sky grows more crowded and the pressure mounts, I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family expects me to honor our traditions, to show I belong. My duty here is to keep hundreds of strangers safe. I can’t be in two places at once, and the choice is tearing me apart.
